intro: Chrysochosma candida var. copelandii, commonly known as the white ghostflower, is a rare and delicate plant native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its unique, star-shaped flowers that are predominantly white with a slight yellowish hue. The plant has a low-growing habit, with narrow, grass-like leaves that help it conserve water in its harsh environment. It blooms during the cooler months, typically in spring, and relies on specific pollinators for reproduction. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
